<Summary source="https://tridenstechnology.com/tesla-sales-statistics/">
# Summary of Tesla Production Statistics Article (February 2026)

## Key Facts Relevant to the Question

**2025 Production Numbers (Primary Answer):**
- **Total production in 2025: 1,654,667 vehicles**
- Breakdown by model category:
  - Model 3/Y: 345,454 units
  - Model X/S/Cybertruck/Semi: 17,161 units
- This represents a **7% decline from 2024**

**Q4 2025 Specific Data:**
- Production: 434,358 vehicles
- Deliveries: 418,227 vehicles

**Historical Production Context:**
The article provides complete annual production data from 2018-2025:
- 2018: 254,530
- 2019: 365,232 (43% growth)
- 2020: 509,737 (40% growth)
- 2021: 930,422 (83% growth)
- 2022: 1,369,611 (47% growth)
- 2023: 1,845,985 (35% growth)
- 2024: 1,773,443 (-4% decline)
- 2025: 1,654,667 (-7% decline)

**Additional Context:**
- 2025 deliveries: 1,636,129 vehicles (8.6% decline from 2024)
- The article notes 2025 marked "the biggest drop in the company's modern history"
- Tesla hit its 9,000,000th vehicle milestone on December 30, 2025
- Total vehicles produced over the past seven years (2018-2025): 7,048,960 units

**Source Attribution:**
The production and delivery figures are attributed to Tesla's official reports and Tesla's Twitter/X account (dated January 2, 2026).
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.statista.com/statistics/502208/tesla-quarterly-vehicle-deliveries/?srsltid=AfmBOop9beewsxQKuGIPfVnjPLAYVvlYJo59QPTF9E0qLJlk1v6mdnvO">
# Summary of Article

**Source:** Statista (accessed February 09, 2026)

**Data Source:** Tesla (October 2, 2025)

## Key Information:

**Important Note:** This article focuses on Tesla **deliveries**, not **production** figures. The forecasting question specifically asks about vehicles **produced**, which is a different metric from deliveries.

### Facts and Statistics:

1. The Statista page presents data on "Number of Tesla vehicles delivered worldwide from 1st quarter 2016 to 3rd quarter 2025 (in 1,000 units)"

2. The data is sourced directly from Tesla and was published/updated on October 2, 2025

3. The data covers through Q3 2025 only (Q4 2025 data would not yet be available as of the October 2, 2025 publication date)

### Limitations:

- The actual numerical values for the quarters are not visible in the extracted web content
- This data tracks **deliveries** rather than **production**, which are distinct metrics (production can exceed or fall short of deliveries in any given period)
- Only covers through Q3 2025, meaning full-year 2025 data would not be complete in this source

**Disclaimer:** The web content extraction appears incomplete as the actual statistical values/numbers from the graph/chart are not included in the extracted text. The page appears to be primarily citation information and navigation elements rather than the substantive data itself.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.best-selling-cars.com/brands/2025-full-year-global-tesla-worldwide-car-sales-by-model-and-outlook-2026-to-2029/">
# Summary of Article: "2025 (Full Year) Global: Tesla Worldwide Car Sales by Model and Outlook 2026 to 2029"

**Source:** Best-selling-cars  
**Date:** January 26, 2026  
**Author:** Henk Bekker

## Key Facts and Statistics:

### 2025 Production and Sales Performance:
- **Total production in 2025:** Down 6.7% compared to 2024
- **Total deliveries (sales) in 2025:** Down 8.6% compared to 2024
- This marks the **second consecutive year** of contraction for both production and sales
- 2025 represents the **third-highest production/sales level ever** for Tesla
- Tesla Model Y remained the best-selling Tesla model worldwide
- "Other Models" (including Cybertruck, Model S, and Model X) saw sharp declines

### Market Position:
- Tesla **lost its position as the world's top electric car brand** in 2025 to BYD
- BYD produced 2,221,918 BEVs and sold 2,256,714 all-electric cars worldwide in 2025
- Tesla lost market share in a growing global all-electric car market

### Regional Performance:
- **Europe (EU, EFTA, UK):** Tesla sales down 28% to 203,382 units (January-November 2025 only; full-year figures not yet released)
- European BEV market grew 27% to 2,276,161 registrations during the same period
- **USA:** Sales hurt by changes in regulations, incentives, and political events
- Cybertruck sales remained well below initial expectations

## Analyst Outlook (Named Source):
Predictions compiled by Tesla from estimates by: Daiwa, DB, Wedbush, Op Co, Canaccord, Baird, Wolfe, Exane, GS, RBC, Evercore ISI, Barclays, Wells Fargo, Morgan Stanley, UBS, Jefferies, Needham & Co, HSBC, Cantor Fitzgerald, and William Blair (end of 2025):
- **2026:** Slight growth predicted
- **2029:** Possible expansion to over 3 million sales

**Note:** The article does not provide the specific 2025 production number in absolute terms, only percentage changes from 2024.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.teslarati.com/tesla-q4-fy-2025-vehicle-delivery-production-results/">
# Summary of Tesla Q4 and FY 2025 Vehicle Delivery and Production Report

**Source:** TESLARATI  
**Date:** January 02, 2026  
**Author:** Simon Alvarez

## Key Facts and Statistics:

### Full Year 2025 Production (Primary Answer to Question):
- **Total vehicles produced in 2025: 1,654,667**
  - Model 3/Y: 1,600,767 units
  - Other models (Model S, Model X, Cybertruck): 53,900 units

### Q4 2025 Production:
- Total: 434,358 vehicles
  - Model 3/Y: 422,652 units
  - Other models: 11,706 units

### Full Year 2025 Deliveries:
- Total: 1,636,129 vehicles
  - Model 3/Y: 1,585,279 units
  - Other models: 50,850 units

### Q4 2025 Deliveries:
- Total: 418,227 vehicles
  - Model 3/Y: 406,585 units
  - Other models: 11,642 units

## Analyst Expectations (Named Source):

**Tesla's company-compiled consensus:**
- Q4 2025 expected deliveries: 422,850 vehicles
- Full year 2025 expected deliveries: 1,640,752 vehicles
- Q4 2025 expected energy storage: 13.4 GWh
- Full year 2025 expected energy storage: 45.9 GWh

## Additional Information:
- Energy storage deployments: 14.2 GWh in Q4 2025 (quarterly record), 46.7 GWh for full year 2025
- Tesla's Q4 and FY 2025 financial results scheduled for January 28, 2026
- Data sourced from Tesla's official report posted January 2, 2026
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.statista.com/statistics/502208/tesla-quarterly-vehicle-deliveries/">
# Summary of Article: "Tesla deliveries by quarter 2025 | Statista"

**Source:** Statista (Content source date: October 2, 2025; Accessed: February 09, 2026)

## Key Information:

**Primary Data:**
- The article references a graph/chart showing "Number of Tesla vehicles delivered worldwide from 1st quarter 2016 to 3rd quarter 2025 (in 1,000 units)"
- Data source: Tesla
- Data published: October 2, 2025
- Coverage period: Q1 2016 through Q3 2025

## Important Notes:

1. **Deliveries vs. Production:** This article focuses on vehicle **deliveries**, not production numbers. The forecasting question specifically asks about vehicles **produced** in 2025, which is a different metric.

2. **Incomplete 2025 Data:** The data only covers through Q3 2025 (first three quarters), meaning Q4 2025 data is not included in this source.

3. **No Specific Numbers Provided:** The extracted web content does not include the actual delivery figures/statistics from the chart - only the title and metadata about the chart are visible in the extraction.

## Disclaimer:
The web content extraction appears incomplete, as it contains primarily the page structure, login prompts, and citation information rather than the actual statistical data from the chart. The specific quarterly delivery numbers that would be most relevant to the forecasting question are not visible in this extraction.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.teslaoracle.com/2026/01/03/tesla-tsla-reports-a-drop-in-q4-and-year-2025-vehicle-deliveries-energy-business-shows-compelling-growth/">
# Summary of Tesla Q4 2025 Vehicle Production and Deliveries Article

## Key Facts and Statistics:

**Q4 2025 Production and Deliveries:**
- Total vehicles produced: 434,358 units (article shows slight discrepancy with 434,385 mentioned in intro)
- Total vehicles delivered: 418,227 units (article shows slight discrepancy with 418,277 mentioned in intro)
- Model 3/Y produced: 422,652 units
- Model 3/Y delivered: 406,585 units
- Other Models produced: 11,706 units
- Other Models delivered: 11,642 units

**Full Year 2025 Production and Deliveries:**
- **Total vehicles produced: 1,654,667 units**
- Total vehicles delivered: 1,636,129 units
- Model 3/Y produced: 1,600,767 units
- Model 3/Y delivered: 1,585,279 units
- Other Models produced: 53,900 units
- Other Models delivered: 50,850 units
- Surplus production over deliveries: 18,538 EVs

**Year-over-Year Comparisons:**
- Q4 2025 deliveries (418,227) vs Q4 2024 deliveries (495,570): decline of 15.6%
- Full year 2025 deliveries (1,636,129) vs 2024 deliveries (1,789,226): decline of approximately 8.6%

**Energy Storage Business:**
- Q4 2025: 14.2 GWh deployed (record)
- Full year 2025: 46.7 GWh deployed
- Full year 2024: 31.4 GWh deployed
- Year-over-year growth: 48.7%

## Opinions and Analysis (from article author):

The article attributes Tesla's sales decline to:
- Elon Musk's political involvement and "entry and exit into politics"
- End of the $7,500 EV tax credit in the United States
- "Anti-Elon Musk sentiment" in the US
- Vandalism of Tesla cars and attacks on Tesla showrooms

The article notes that BYD overtook Tesla as the global leader in EV sales with 2.26 million EVs sold in 2025.

**Note:** The article contains minor numerical discrepancies between the introductory paragraph and the data tables for Q4 2025 figures.
</Summary>

<Asknews_articles>
Query: How many vehicles will Tesla report producing in 2025?
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Volkswagen Surpasses Tesla as Europe's Top Electric Car Seller in 2025**
Volkswagen (VW) has surpassed Tesla to become Europe's top pure-electric vehicle (EV) seller in 2025, according to Jato Dynamics. VW sold approximately 275,000 all-electric vehicles across Europe, a 56% increase from the previous year, driven largely by strong demand for models like the ID 7. In contrast, Tesla's European sales declined by 27% to 237,000 vehicles, attributed to a limited product lineup and rising competition from Chinese manufacturers. Despite this, Tesla's Model Y remained the best-selling EV model in Europe, though its sales dropped by 28%. The Skoda Elroq (a VW Group model) ranked second, followed by the Tesla Model 3, which saw a 24% sales decline. Overall, the European EV market grew by 29%, with EVs capturing 20% of new registrations, up from previous years. Jato Dynamics cited not only Chinese brands but also European models produced in China—such as the Mini Cooper, Dacia Spring, and Cupra Tavascan—as key factors in increased competition. Additionally, Tesla's declining sales were linked to Elon Musk's involvement in U.S. politics and a 36% drop in brand value. However, Tesla's stock performance diverged sharply: the share price reached a record high of $499 in December 2025, driven by investor confidence in the Robotaxi and humanoid robot Optimus projects.
Original language: de
Publish date: February 08, 2026 06:09 PM
Source:[t3n Magazin](https://t3n.de/news/tesla-volkswagen-e-autos-europa-1728649/)

**Tesla's Future Vision Drives Massive Investment Surge Amid Mixed Financial Results and High Valuation**
Tesla's stock reacted with a significant decline following the release of its 2025 financial results on January 28, 2026, despite a slight recovery afterward. The company reported a 3.1% year-over-year decline in Q4 revenue to $24.9 billion, slightly below analysts' estimates of $25.11 billion. Electric vehicle sales dropped 15.6% to 418,227 units, attributed to the expiration of U.S. subsidies in September 2024, which led to a pre-emptive surge in purchases during Q3. The 'pure' auto revenue, excluding CO2 credits and leasing, fell 10.2% to $16.8 billion. However, the gross margin in the auto segment improved from 15.4% to 17.9% on a quarter-over-quarter basis. The energy and storage, as well as service, businesses performed strongly. Overall, EBIT declined 10% year-over-year to $1.41 billion, with a margin of 5.7%, slightly below the prior year’s 6.2% but above the $1.32 billion expectation. The adjusted earnings per share dropped 31.5% to $0.50, capital expenditures decreased 14% to $2.4 billion, and free cash flow fell 30% to $1.4 billion. Elon Musk emphasized that 2025 was a pivotal year as Tesla transitioned from a hardware-focused business to a physical AI company, prioritizing Full Self-Driving (FSD), the Robo-Taxi Cybercab, Optimus robots, and AI. FSD user count rose 38% to 1.1 million, though 70% were prepaying customers; from the current quarter, FSD is only available via a $99 monthly subscription, which Musk warned would pressure near-term auto profitability. Musk did not forecast auto sales growth for 2026, with Model S and X production ending in Q2 2026 to shift toward Optimus production, with the Optimus Gen 3 launch expected by end-2026. The Cybercab and Tesla Semi volume production is also planned for 2026. Massive investments are expected in solar cells, batteries, AI infrastructure, and in-house AI chips. Capital expenditures are projected to exceed $20 billion in 2026—a rise of at least 135% from 2025. Musk is also considering building a proprietary chip fabrication plant, citing that Samsung, TSMC, and Micron may not meet Tesla’s chip demand within 3–4 years. Additionally, Tesla is investing $2.0 billion in xAI, Musk’s AI venture, with deep collaboration expected. For 2025, revenue declined 2.9% to $94.8 billion. Analysts project 2026 revenue to grow 10.1% to $104.4 billion, with EBIT increasing 44.2% to $6.3 billion, improving the margin from 4.6% to 6.0%. The market capitalization stands at $1.56 trillion, with an enterprise value of $1.52 trillion after deducting $35.7 billion in net cash. This implies a 242.0x EV/EBIT multiple for 2026, indicating an extremely high valuation, with the 2027 multiple at 88.9x based on a projected EBIT of $17.1 billion—still astronomically high and contingent on over 50% growth. The 2026 P/E ratio is 141.7. Despite skepticism about Tesla’s ability to execute Musk’s ambitious vision amid rising competition in EVs, autonomous driving, robotics, and AI, the stock may continue sideways movement as investors remain optimistic. A surprise announcement from Musk could reignite enthusiasm and drive the stock toward record highs. The high volatility is reflected in discount certificates on Tesla, such as the one with ISIN DE000PJ79EX2, offering a maximum potential return of 16.2% (26.4% p.a.) if the stock remains above $370 at maturity on September 18, 2026; the break-even point is $318.40.

**Automotive and Parts Industry Weekly Report: Tesla's Third-Generation Robot Set to Launch...**
The automotive and auto parts industry weekly report highlights a -5.08% decline in the auto sector, with commercial vehicles performing best among sub-sectors. The CSI 300 rose 0.08%, while the S&P China Auto Index fell -5.08%, ranking 29th out of 31 sectors. Sub-sectors saw declines: commercial vehicles +0.33%, passenger vehicles -4.83%, motorcycles and others -5.59%, auto parts -5.74%, and auto services -6.99%. Top gainers included Xishanghai (+13.31%), Dongli Xinke (+13.03%), Xingyu Stock (+11.19%), Qingdao Shuangxing (+10.11%), and Huapeng Power (+8.91%); worst performers were Tianpu Stock (-28.94%), Jinlong Bus (-21.81%), Chaojie Stock (-19.17%), Weitang Industry (-18.92%), and Kaimeng Stock (-16.93%). In January 2025, BYD sold 210,100 vehicles (50.0% MoM drop), Geely 270,200 (+14.1% MoM), Chery 200,300 (-18.2% MoM), and Great Wall 90,300 (-27.2% MoM). New energy vehicle makers: Harmony Intelligent Mobility sold 57,900 (-35.4% MoM), Zero Motorcycles 32,100 (-46.9% MoM), Xiaomi over 39,000, NIO 27,200, Li Auto 27,700, and XPeng 20,000. The Ministry of Finance projected that over 11.5 million cars will be replaced under the 2025 'old-for-new' policy, with new energy vehicles accounting for nearly 60% of sales. Shanghai offers up to 15,000 RMB in subsidies for new energy vehicle purchases and up to 13,000 RMB for vehicles under 2.0L. Tesla announced its third-generation humanoid robot will be unveiled, designed from first principles, capable of learning from human behavior, with a planned annual production capacity of 1 million units starting in late 2026 at the Fremont plant.长安汽车 aims to achieve mass production of humanoid robots by 2028 and launch commercial air taxi flights by 2030. The automotive industry's profit margin dropped to 1.8% in December 2025, down from 4.1% in December 2024, with annual average profit margin at 4.1%—the second consecutive year at historic lows, below the 5.9% industrial average. Revenue fell 0.8% YoY, costs rose 0.8% YoY, and profit fell 57.4% YoY due to pricing pressure and high production costs. Aptiv completed the spin-off of its Electrical Distribution Systems (EDS) business as Versigent (VGNT) on April 1, 2026. Eaton plans to split its Vehicle & Vehicle Electrification Group into a standalone company, expected by Q1 2027. A new mandatory national standard for automotive steering systems will take effect on July 1, 2026, setting technical and safety requirements for line-by-line steering, traditional systems, and auxiliary devices. Zijin Motor announced the launch of the LS9 Hyper SUV, the first production SUV with full-line electronic steering, certified by the China Automotive Center for reliability, and equipped with SAIC's first mass-produced three-motor vector four-wheel drive system. Investment recommendations include intelligent vehicles, auto parts with overseas growth potential, and components with domestic substitution potential. Suggested stocks: Beijing Automotive (BAIC Blue Valley), Bortel (Berthel), Yinlun Co., Longsheng Tech, Baolong Tech, Zhejiang Xiantong, Haoneng Co., Lingyun Co., Huguang Co. Small-cap picks: Baihehua, Kejie Smart. Risks include underperformance in domestic and international sales, poor new model performance, supply chain issues, slow intelligentization, and intensified competition.

**Korea’s Electric Vehicle Milestone: 1 Million Units by 2026, But Policy Overhaul Needed**
South Korea's electric vehicle (EV) registration is projected to surpass 1 million units by the first half of 2026, 15 years after Hyundai Motor Group launched its first EV, the 'Blue On,' in 2011. As of the end of 2025, domestic pure EV stock reached 899,000 units, with an estimated 910,000 units by January 2026. Accelerated by early confirmation of national EV subsidies, new and updated model releases, and price reductions, EV sales have surged—exceeding 200,000 units annually for the first time in 2025 and overcoming a temporary market plateau. With monthly sales averaging 20,000–30,000 units (excluding January), analysts expect cumulative EV registrations to cross 1 million by March–April 2026. However, rapid EV growth is accompanied by growing concerns over market erosion by foreign EVs, particularly from China. The domestic EV share is declining while imported EVs surpassed 30% of the market for the first time in 2025, with BYD and Tesla each selling over 1,000 units in January 2026. As a result, experts emphasize the need to move beyond current subsidy policies and implement strategic industrial support to strengthen the domestic EV sector. Stronger incentives for high-performance, low-cost domestically produced EVs are being advocated to boost consumer preference. KAMA Chairman Kang Nam-hoon stressed the urgency of maintaining and enhancing domestic production capacity, calling for expanded production tax credits to ensure local EVs gain real market competitiveness.
Original language: ko
Publish date: February 08, 2026 07:00 AM
Source:[IT 전문 뉴스포털 전자신문](https://www.etnews.com/20260206000223?SNS=00002)

**Tesla Puts Its Money Where Its Mouth Is in the Biggest Way Possible**
Tesla announced it will end production of its high-end Model S and Model X vehicles in the second quarter of 2026, repurposing the California factory space for the assembly line of its humanoid robot, Optimus. According to CEO Elon Musk, this marks an 'honorable discharge' of the Model S and X programs as Tesla shifts focus toward autonomy, AI, and robotics. The move follows prior steps: Tesla stopped accepting new orders for the Model S and X in China in April 2025 due to tariffs and in Europe by late 2025 due to low demand. Combined deliveries of the Model S, Model X, and Cybertruck totaled 50,850 units in 2025—just over 3% of Tesla’s total 1.6 million vehicle deliveries. This strategic pivot signals Tesla’s transformation beyond being solely an electric vehicle manufacturer, with long-term goals including producing up to one million Optimus robots annually. The article emphasizes that this shift increases uncertainty, but also offers high upside, urging investors to reassess their original investment thesis and determine whether they still align with Tesla’s evolving vision. The Motley Fool notes that Tesla is once again 'shooting for the stars' and 'putting its money where its mouth is,' but cautions that this is not an investment for everyone.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 07, 2026 09:50 PM
Source:[The Motley Fool](https://www.fool.com/investing/2026/02/07/tesla-puts-its-money-where-its-mouth-is-in-the-big/?source=newstex&utm_source=newstex&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=article&referring_guid=135e03cf-7b81-48cd-b5f8-551d2536d47e)

**Tesla Puts Its Money Where Its Mouth Is in the Biggest Way Possible | The Motley Fool**
Tesla (TSLA) announced it will discontinue production of the Model S sedan and Model X crossover in the second quarter of 2026, repurposing the California factory for the assembly of its humanoid Optimus robot, as stated by CEO Elon Musk during the company’s January earnings call. Musk described the move as an 'honorable discharge' of the Model S and X programs, signaling Tesla’s strategic pivot toward autonomy, artificial intelligence (AI), and robotics. This decision follows declining demand: Tesla stopped accepting new orders for the Model S and X in China in April 2025 due to high tariffs, and effectively ended new orders in Europe by late 2025. In 2025, combined deliveries of the Model S, Model X, and Cybertruck accounted for just 50,850 units—3% of Tesla’s total 1.6 million vehicle deliveries. The shift marks a pivotal moment for investors, as Tesla transitions from being primarily an automaker to a broader technology company focused on AI, driverless vehicles, and robotics, with a long-term goal of producing one million Optimus robots annually. While the move reflects Tesla’s continued commitment to ambitious innovation, it also increases business uncertainty, making the investment more speculative. The article emphasizes that Tesla is 'shooting for the stars and putting its money where its mouth is,' urging investors to reassess whether they are aligned with Tesla’s evolving vision.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 07, 2026 09:50 PM
Source:[The Motley Fool](https://www.fool.com/investing/2026/02/07/tesla-puts-its-money-where-its-mouth-is-in-the-big/)

**Volkswagen Surpasses Tesla in European Electric Vehicle Sales in 2025**
Volkswagen became the leader in electric vehicle sales in Europe in 2025, selling 274,300 fully electric cars, surpassing Tesla, which sold 236,400 units in the same region. According to an analysis by Jato Dynamics published on February 5, 2026, Volkswagen's sales increased by 56% compared to 2024. The growth is attributed primarily to the success of new models, especially the mid-size ID.7. In contrast, Tesla's sales declined by 27% year-on-year, partly due to its reliance on outdated vehicle models and reputational challenges stemming from CEO Elon Musk's support of far-right political parties in Europe. A recent study cited by Tagesschau indicates that Tesla has the worst brand reputation among companies in Germany.
Original language: uk
Publish date: February 07, 2026 07:45 PM

**Discontinuing Flagship Models: What's Behind Tesla's Strategic Pivot to AI and Robotics?**
Tesla has announced the discontinuation of its Model S and Model X vehicles starting in the next quarter, according to CEO Elon Musk, who stated that the move marks the 'glorious retirement' of these flagship models as Tesla transitions toward a future centered on autonomous driving and robotics. The two models, produced at Tesla's Fremont, California factory since their launch in 2012 and 2015 respectively, have cumulatively sold over 2 million units and played a pivotal role in transforming Tesla from a startup into an industry leader. However, with Model Y and Model 3 now serving as the primary sales drivers, and increasing competition from Chinese EV brands like BYD, NIO, and Huawei-backed AVATR (e.g., Aito M9,尊界S800), Tesla's market position has eroded. In 2025, Tesla reported $94.827 billion in revenue (a 3% decline year-on-year) and $3.794 billion in net profit (a 46% drop), while its global EV production and deliveries reached 1.655 million and 1.636 million units, respectively—both surpassed by BYD, which delivered 2.25 million pure-electric vehicles in 2025, marking the first time Tesla was overtaken in annual EV sales by a Chinese automaker. Tesla plans to redirect resources from Model S/X production to the development of the Optimus humanoid robot and the rollout of the Cybercab robotaxi, with the third-generation Optimus set for release in Q1 2026 and Robotaxi operations expanding in Austin and the San Francisco Bay Area. In 2025, Tesla's Robotaxi fleet had driven over 2 million kilometers collectively. The company increased its operating expenses by 23% to $12.7 billion in 2025, with significant investments in autonomous driving and AI infrastructure. Capital expenditures are projected to rise from $8.53 billion in 2025 to over $20 billion in 2026, funding six new factories and AI computing upgrades. Additionally, Tesla committed $2 billion to Elon Musk’s AI startup xAI. Musk described the shift as 'slightly regrettable' but essential for Tesla’s transformation into an 'AI and robotics company,' where service revenue from Robotaxi and robotics could eventually surpass vehicle sales as the primary profit driver. The discontinuation of Model S and Model X is thus framed not as an end, but as a strategic pivot toward a future defined by artificial intelligence and automation.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 07, 2026 11:07 AM
Source:[新浪财经](https://finance.sina.com.cn/stock/t/2026-02-07/doc-inhkyvrf1198415.shtml)

**Tesla Shanghai Factory Delivers 852,000 Vehicles in 2025, Accounting for Over Half of Global Deliveries**
According to market data released on February 5, 2026, the Tesla Shanghai Gigafactory delivered 851,732 domestically produced electric vehicles in 2025. This represents a 7.1% decrease from the 916,660 units delivered in 2024 but still accounts for 52.06% of Tesla's global annual delivery volume. Tesla officials have confirmed that the Shanghai factory's deliveries exceeded half of Tesla's total global deliveries in 2025. The factory held an annual review event on February 4, 2026, which corroborated the delivery figures. In addition to vehicle production, the adjacent energy storage Gigafactory achieved large-scale production in 2025 and has been supplying products stably to both domestic and international markets. According to Tesla's official data, the company produced 1,654,667 electric vehicles globally in 2025, with 1,636,129 delivered. Based on authoritative industry statistics, the Shanghai factory's output constitutes a clear majority, reinforcing its role as a core production hub.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 05, 2026 11:29 PM
Source:[中关村在线](https://auto.zol.com.cn/1130/11305129.html)

**Tesla Vice President Tao Lin: Shanghai Gigafactory to Deliver Over Half of Global Tesla Vehicles in 2025**
According to Tao Lin, Vice President of Tesla, the Shanghai Gigafactory delivered more than half of Tesla's global vehicle deliveries in 2025, marking a significant milestone in the company's global operations. The factory's output reached 851,000 vehicles in 2025, accounting for 52% of Tesla's total global deliveries of approximately 1,636,129 units. This surpasses the 2024 delivery volume of 916,000 vehicles from the Shanghai plant, which already represented half of Tesla’s global deliveries that year. Additionally, the Shanghai Gigafactory’s energy storage production capacity began supplying multiple international markets. Official data confirms Tesla’s 2025 global production totaled 1,654,667 vehicles, with 46.7 GWh of energy storage deployed. The Shanghai facility remains Tesla’s largest export hub.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 05, 2026 04:42 AM
Source:[凤凰网（凤凰新媒体）](https://tech.ifeng.com/c/8qUhKPyslVg)

**Tesla Global Owners Exceed 9 Million, Adding Nearly 1 Million in Six Months**
According to a report by Sina Finance, global Tesla vehicle owners have surpassed 9 million, with the milestone reached as of February 4, 2026. The figure is based on a post by Tesla China on its official Weibo account, which announced that the company had reached 9 million owners, celebrating the Lunar New Year with the message 'Full power, fully charged, five blessings arriving, summoning lucky fish.' This marks an increase of nearly 1 million new owners in the past six months, as Tesla China had previously reported over 8 million owners in July and August 2025. The milestone coincides with the production of Tesla’s 9 millionth vehicle, which was completed at the Shanghai Gigafactory on December 30, 2025. The vast majority of Tesla’s vehicles produced are Model 3 and Model Y models, most of which remain in active use, supporting the high owner count.
Original language: zh

**Global Tesla Owners Surpass 9 Million, Driven by Production Capacity and Market Recognition**
As of February 4, 2026, the number of global Tesla vehicle owners has surpassed 9 million, according to a recent post on Tesla China's official social media platform, which stated, 'Celebrating the Lunar New Year with 9 million global owners.' This confirms that the actual number of active Tesla owners has reached this milestone. Earlier, between July and August 2025, Tesla China had mentioned that global owners exceeded 8 million on three occasions, indicating an increase of approximately 1 million new owners in the past six months, reflecting a steady growth trend. This user base aligns closely with Tesla's production pace: the 9 millionth Tesla vehicle was officially rolled off the production line at the Shanghai Gigafactory on December 30, 2025. Given that the Model 3 and Model Y have consistently dominated production and vehicles have a long average service life, the current vehicle ownership level closely matches cumulative production. Thus, the milestone of 9 million owners is both a natural outcome of production accumulation and a strong indicator of market acceptance and long-term customer retention.

**Tesla Abandons Model S/X: 'We Can't Profit Only from Car Sales'**
Tesla reported its 2025 full-year financial results on January 28, 2025, with total vehicle deliveries at 1.6361 million units, a 8.6% decline year-on-year. Model 3/Y deliveries totaled 1.5853 million units (down 7.0%), while Model S/X deliveries fell by over 40% to 50,900 units. As a result, automotive revenue declined 10% to $69.526 billion, total revenue dropped 3% to $94.827 billion (the first decline), and net profit (GAAP) fell 46% to $3.794 billion. In the earnings call, CEO Elon Musk announced the phased shutdown of Model S and Model X production, with the Fremont factory's S/X line repurposed for the production of Optimus humanoid robots, aiming for 1 million units annually. Tesla’s strategy now emphasizes automation and software, with FSD (Full Self-Driving) subscriptions reaching 1.1 million users by 2025, or 12% of total vehicle ownership. The company plans to launch the third-generation Optimus robot in Q1 2026, featuring a redesigned hand. Tesla is also advancing the Cybercab (a robotaxi without pedals or steering wheel) and the electric Semi for 2026 production. Cybercab is expected to operate 50–60 hours per week, compared to 10–11 for human-driven vehicles. Management believes these services could expand Tesla’s market size 5–10 times. In 2025, R&D spending reached $6.411 billion, and capital expenditure was $8.527 billion, with 2026 capital spending projected to exceed $20 billion. Funds will support lithium refining, LFP battery plants, Megapack, Optimus, Cybercab, Semi, AI infrastructure, and Robotaxi fleet expansion. Tesla’s CFO Vaibhav Taneja stated that the company’s investments are not optional but essential for survival. Despite challenges in China, where Tesla’s sales declined 5% in 2025, the company remains strong in markets like Malaysia, Norway, Poland, and Saudi Arabia—regions where FSD is not yet available. Musk acknowledged China as the biggest competitor in humanoid robotics due to AI and manufacturing advantages, but claimed Tesla is the only company with capabilities in real-world AI, mechanical dexterity, and mass production.

**Tesla Halts Model S and Model X Production to Redirect Focus Toward Humanoid Robots**
Starting in the second quarter of 2026, Tesla will permanently discontinue production of the Model S and Model X. Elon Musk explained the decision during a presentation, stating, 'It is time to conclude the Model S and Model X programs with a honorable exit, because we are moving toward a future defined by autonomy.' The move aims to free up production capacity at Tesla’s Fremont, California plant to accelerate large-scale manufacturing of Optimus, the company’s humanoid robot. This strategic shift redefines Tesla’s priorities, redirecting resources—industrial, human, and financial—toward robotics and autonomy as central growth drivers. The decision comes amid a global decline in Tesla’s commercial performance, particularly in premium vehicle sales, which dropped 40.2% year-on-year, with only 50,850 units sold in the 'other models' category (including Model S, Model X, and Cybertruck) in the past year. In response, Tesla has intensified focus on lower-priced versions of the Model 3 and Model Y. Despite price cuts, the company reported a profit decline exceeding 60% in Q4 2025, indicating that revenue recovery remains elusive. Optimus has become the primary investment focus. The third-generation model, expected to be unveiled in Q1 2026, features improved hand design for greater precision in tasks. Musk previously described Optimus as 'the greatest product ever created' and claimed it could perform any task—teaching, childcare, dog walking, lawn mowing, social interaction, or cocktail preparation. The robot is projected to be priced between $20,000 and $30,000, with initial sales expected by late 2027. This robotics push is tied to a $1 trillion executive compensation plan approved by Tesla’s board in November, contingent on achieving long-term goals including a $8.5 trillion market valuation, selling 20 million vehicles, operating a million robotaxis, and selling a million humanoid robots. Analyst Seth Goldstein of Morningstar noted that Musk’s full compensation package hinges on Tesla becoming a leader in both autonomous vehicles and humanoid robots across multiple countries.

**Global Electric Vehicle Sales in 2025: China and the U.S. Show Opposite Trends**
In 2025, global electric vehicle (EV) registrations increased by 20%, reaching 20.7 million units. China led with 12.9 million registrations, a 17% increase from 2024; Europe recorded 4.3 million (a 33% rise); and the rest of the world saw 1.7 million (a 48% increase). In contrast, EV sales in the United States grew by only 1%, with Tesla experiencing a 9% decline in vehicle deliveries and a 46% drop in net profit. Elon Musk announced a strategic shift toward artificial intelligence and robotics. The U.S. market saw EVs account for less than 10% of new car sales, while 39 countries exceeded 10% EV adoption—Vietnam (38%), Thailand (21%), and Indonesia (15%). In 2025, President Donald Trump returned to office and pledged to end EV-supporting policies, reducing federal incentives. Meanwhile, Europe maintained a 90% CO₂ reduction target for vehicles by 2035, Germany offered subsidies of €1,500–€6,000 for EVs, Brazil’s MOVER program linked tax credits to domestic EV production, South Africa introduced a 150% tax deduction for EV and battery manufacturing, and Thailand provided production-linked subsidies and tax reductions. China, having matured its EV industry after a decade of state support, replaced full tax exemptions with a 5% reduced tax on EV purchases, as domestic saturation and intense competition prompted Chinese manufacturers to expand globally.

**Tesla's High Capital Expenditure Drives AI-Driven Transformation in the Automotive Industry**
Tesla released its 2025 annual report on January 29, 2025, revealing a shift from a car sales-dependent model to an AI-driven technology platform. Despite short-term profitability pressure and high capital expenditures, Tesla demonstrated revenue resilience through strong growth in energy and storage businesses. In Q4 2025, revenue reached $24.9 billion, down 3% year-on-year, with automotive revenue at $17.6 billion (down 3%) and energy/storage revenue at $3.8 billion (up 25% year-on-year, gross margin 28.6%). Service and other revenue was $3.4 billion (up 25%). Non-GAAP net profit was $1.8 billion, down 16%. Automotive deliveries were 418,200 units, down 16%, with unit manufacturing cost reduced to ~$35,000 and Q4 gross margin reaching 20.1%, the highest in two years. For 2025, total revenue was $94.8 billion, a historic decline of 3% year-on-year, driven by a 10% drop in automotive revenue ($69.5 billion), a 27% increase in energy/storage ($12.8 billion), and a 19% rise in service and other ($12.5 billion). Non-GAAP net profit fell 26% to $5.9 billion, primarily due to lower average vehicle prices and reduced regulatory credit income. Annual deliveries totaled 1.64 million, down 9%, with Model 3/Y deliveries at 1.59 million (down 7%). The company's energy storage deployment reached 46.7 GWh in 2025, up 48.7% year-on-year, with Q4 deployment at 14.2 GWh (up 13% quarter-on-quarter). The Shanghai Lingang factory produced ~26 GWh, accounting for 56% of total output, primarily exported to Australia, Europe, and Japan. Megapack 3 is scheduled for production in Houston in 2026, targeting 50 GWh annual capacity and a 20% increase in single-unit capacity. The Autobidder platform integrates AI-based price forecasting and trading, enabling participation in electricity markets and promoting asset financialization and customer stickiness. Powerwall global installations surpassed one million units. Tesla's market share in Australia's grid-scale storage reached 35%, securing a 1.2 GWh order for Phase III and a 0.5 GWh project in Japan’s Miwakura Lake East Storage Facility, expected to be operational by 2027 and become one of Japan’s largest. Tesla is building the only lithium and cathode refining plant in the U.S. and plans 100 GWh solar cell capacity to support AI data centers and the grid. In 2026, Tesla plans capital expenditures exceeding $20 billion, a 135% increase year-on-year, focused on AI compute infrastructure, chip R&D, robotaxis, robotics, and battery/factory construction (excluding solar and semiconductor wafer investments). In January 2026, Tesla invested $2 billion in xAI and signed a collaboration agreement to deepen AI research and data training, leveraging the Grok large model to enhance fleet management and model training efficiency. The company plans to develop its own AI5/AI6 chips: AI5 offers 8x the compute and 9x the memory of AI4, while AI6 aims for 2x AI5 performance, with a single chip reaching 5,000 TOPS. A planned in-house wafer fab will target initial capacity of 100,000 wafers/month, scaling to 1 million/month, approaching TSMC’s global monthly output of 1.47 million. Tesla will also optimize its vehicle lineup: Model S/X are expected to be largely discontinued by Q2 2026, with the Fremont factory repurposed for 1 million Optimus robots annually. The first mass-production-ready Optimus Gen3 is planned for Q1 2026, with industrial production in 2026 and public sales in 2027. The next-generation Roadster may debut in April. Semi-truck production is planned for H1 2026. Full Self-Driving (FSD) software will transition from one-time purchase to subscription starting March 31, 2026: $199/month for general users, $99/month for enhanced package holders. As of 2025, Tesla had 1.1 million FSD subscribers, with ~70% still using one-time purchase. The subscription model lowers entry barriers and enhances long-term revenue predictability. FSD has accumulated 7 billion miles driven, strengthening its data moat. FSD is now live in South Korea and open for test drives in multiple European countries. Robotaxi operations are advancing: 500 vehicles are operating with paid passengers in the Bay Area and Austin, with safety drivers removed in Austin in January 2026, marking a key milestone. By H1 2026, operations are expected to expand to 9 cities, with coverage reaching 25%-50% of the U.S. by year-end. The driverless Cybercab, without steering wheels or pedals, will begin production in April. Tesla’s high investment and commercialization success are accelerating China’s auto industry toward embodied intelligence. Xpeng plans to launch a Robotaxi by 2026. Xiaomi plans to launch a cooking robot in 2026 and a care robot in 2027. Li Auto is restarting robot R&D, aiming to release a prototype in 1-2 years and small-scale industrial use in 2027. Other automakers are also announcing plans. Tesla’s integrated system of large models, algorithms, chips, and data has validated the transferability of autonomous driving technology to robotics, reshaping long-term valuation models from car sales alone to multi-revenue streams of cars, AI, and robotics. Chinese automakers with strong autonomous driving capabilities, full-stack integration, and execution strength are poised to benefit most from the intelligence-driven value shift. Investment recommendation: In 2026, high-end autonomous driving may enter large-scale commercialization. Automakers with full-stack self-research capabilities in large models, algorithms, chips, and data loops will lead in technology deployment and user experience, widening the gap with competitors and benefiting most from product premium and valuation uplift, accelerating industry concentration. Recommended stocks: XPeng (9868.HK), Xiaomi (1810.HK), Li Auto-W (2015.HK), Zhihong (9863.HK), Changan (000625.SZ), Great Wall (601633.SH), SAIC (600104.SH). Risks: Slower-than-expected progress in autonomous driving and robotics; insufficient policy support; intensifying industry competition.

**Tesla 2025 Financial Report: Global EV Production Reaches 1.655 Million, Deliveries Hit 1.636 Million**
Tesla officially released its Q4 and full-year 2025 financial results on January 29, 2026. In 2025, Tesla produced approximately 1.655 million electric vehicles globally and delivered 1.636 million, with the Model Y topping sales in multiple markets and achieving record delivery volumes in the Asia-Pacific region. Energy storage installations reached 46.7 gigawatt-hours (GWh), a 48.7% year-on-year increase, with Q4 installations at 14.2 GWh—up 13% quarter-over-quarter—and both Q4 and annual storage figures setting new records. The Shanghai Gigafactory delivered 851,000 vehicles in 2025, accounting for over half of Tesla’s global deliveries, and the Model Y remained the best-selling SUV in China. In the earnings call, Elon Musk stated that advancements in AI and robotics will enable 'a highly affluent, extraordinary world' rather than just 'basic income.' He emphasized ongoing efforts to improve safety, reduce costs, and ensure access to desired goods without compromising environmental quality. Tesla now has over 9 million global owners. On January 21, 2026, Tesla updated its mission to 'building an extraordinary world.' Musk highlighted that full-scale autonomous driving and the development of Tesla Robotaxi will fundamentally transform transportation, while humanoid robots could free humans from repetitive labor, advancing societal prosperity.

**Tesla's Q4 2025 Deliveries at 418,227 Units, Below Market Expectations**
Tesla reported its Q4 2025 vehicle production and delivery data on January 2, 2026. The company delivered 418,227 vehicles and produced 434,358 vehicles in the quarter, resulting in an annual delivery volume of 1.64 million and an annual production of approximately 1.65 million. This falls short of Wall Street's expected delivery figure of around 426,000 vehicles for the quarter. Compared to Q4 2024, when Tesla delivered 495,570 vehicles and produced 459,445 vehicles, the Q4 2025 delivery volume declined by approximately 16%, and production decreased by 5.5%. On an annual basis, Tesla's deliveries dropped from 1.79 million in 2024 to 1.64 million in 2025, representing an 8.6% year-over-year decrease—the second consecutive year of annual decline. **Tesla Hits 9 Million Vehicles as 2025 Comes to a Close**
Tesla has reached a milestone of producing its 9 millionth vehicle globally, with the vehicle rolling off the production line at Gigafactory Shanghai on December 30, 2025. The achievement was confirmed in a post by Tesla Asia on X, which included a photo of the Giga Shanghai team celebrating with a white Model Y. The milestone reflects cumulative global production across all Tesla factories, not just the Shanghai site. The company reached eight million vehicles just 207 days earlier, indicating a production rate of one million vehicles in under seven months—a significant acceleration in 2025. Gigafactory Shanghai has been central to this growth, having produced four million vehicles alone and now accounting for nearly half of Tesla’s total global production. The factory also produced its five millionth battery pack in late 2025, supporting ongoing vehicle output and regional variants like the Model Y L in China. Tesla Senior Vice President of Automotive Tom Zhu praised the global factory teams and thanked owners for their support. The milestone underscores Tesla’s rapid scaling and suggests the next million vehicles may be produced even faster. The Model Y also secured its third consecutive year as the world’s best-selling car in 2025, while Starlink doubled its user base to approximately 9.2 million by year-end.

**Expert: China to Produce Nearly 8 Million Electric Vehicles in 2025**
According to industry expert Ferdinand Dudenhöffer, China is expected to produce nearly 8 million electric vehicles (EVs) in 2025, up from 6.5 million in the first nine months of the year—a 45% increase compared to the same period the previous year. Dudenhöffer forecasts total 2025 production at 7.9 million, with continued growth beyond that. This production surge is outpacing the global EV sales growth, which rose by 36% in the same period according to PwC. China’s share of global EV production is therefore increasing. In contrast, Germany produced approximately 916,000 pure EVs in the first nine months of the year, according to VDA data. BYD is the leading EV manufacturer in China, responsible for nearly 1.6 million units—about a quarter of the total—followed by Geely (836,000) and Tesla (603,000). Dudenhöffer emphasizes that China is solidifying its role as the global center for EV production, posing a significant challenge for Germany’s automotive industry, as the gap between the two nations continues to widen.
